Subseries V.A: National Coordinating Center in Solidarity with Chile

Following the military led coup d'Ã©tat on September 11, 1973 which overthrew the Chilean socialist government led by Salvador Allende and resulted in a military dictatorship, thousands of Chileans were arrested, killed, or disappeared. The National Coordinating Center in Solidarity with Chile, based in New York City, was one of several campaigns worldwide established in response to the coup and its aftermath. The CPUSA played a key role in the Center's formation and activities. This subseries contains correspondence of the Center, much of it to/from national coordinator (and Communist Party activist) Susan Borenstein, as well as correspondence of Beatriz Allende and Hortensia Bussi de Allende (respectively, Salvatore Allende's daughter and widow). Some highlights include files related to the activities of Chile Democratico; materials on the Partido Comunista de Chile and its leader Luis Corvalan; documents on the plight of Chilean health care workers and trade unionists; and records on the tortured, the disappeared, and the exiled.
